column1: New Brunswick is a city in Middlesex County
column2: New Jersey
column4: in the New York metropolitan area. The city is the county seat of Middlesex County
column5: and the home of Rutgers University. New Brunswick is on the Northeast Corridor rail line
column7: on the southern bank of the Raritan River.

column12: New Brunswick is known as both the Hub City and the Healthcare City. The corporate headquarters and production facilities of several global pharmaceutical companies are situated in the city
column13: including Johnson & Johnson and Bristol-Myers Squibb.

column1: New Brunswick is noted for its ethnic diversity. At one time
column2: one quarter of the Hungarian population of New Jersey resided in the city and in the 1930s one out of three city residents was Hungarian. The Hungarian community continues as a cohesive community
column4: 200 Hungarian residents accounting for 8% of the population of New Brunswick in 1992. Growing Asian and Hispanic communities have developed around French Street near Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital.

column1: The area around present-day New Brunswick was first inhabited by the Lenape Native Americans
column2: whose Minisink Trail intersected the Raritan River and followed a route that would be taken by later colonial roads. The first European settlement at the site of New Brunswick was made in 1681. The settlement here was called Prigmore's Swamp (1681–1697)
column3: then known as Inian's Ferry (1691–1714). In 1714
column4: the settlement was given the name New Brunswick
column5: after the city of Braunschweig (Brunswick in Low German)
column7: which is now in Germany. Braunschweig was an influential and powerful city in the Hanseatic League and was an administrative seat for the Duchy of Hanover. Shortly after the first settlement of New Brunswick in colonial New Jersey
column8: George
column9: Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg and Elector of Hanover
column10: became King George I of Great Britain. Alternatively
column11: the city gets its name from King George II of Great Britain

column1: === During the Colonial and Early American periods ===
Centrally located between New York City and Philadelphia along an early thoroughfare known as the King's Highway and situated along the Raritan River
column2: New Brunswick became an important hub for Colonial travelers and traders. New Brunswick was incorporated as a town in 1736 and chartered as a city in 1784. It was incorporated into a town in 1798 as part of the Township Act of 1798. It was occupied by the British in the winter of 1776–1777 during the Revolutionary War.The Declaration of Independence received one of its first public readings
column3: by Colonel John Neilson in New Brunswick on July 9
column5: in the days following its promulgation by the Continental Congress. A bronze statue marking the event was dedicated on July 9
column8: in front of the Heldrich Hotel.The Trustees of Queen's College (now Rutgers University)
column10: voted by a margin of ten to seven in 1771 to locate the young college in New Brunswick
column13: New Jersey. Classes began in 1771 with one instructor
column16: and several freshmen at a tavern called the 'Sign of the Red Lion' on the corner of Albany and Neilson Streets (now the grounds of the Johnson & Johnson corporate headquarters); Leydt would become the university's first graduate in 1774
column17: when he was the only member of the graduating class. The Sign of the Red Lion was purchased on behalf of Queens College in 1771
column18: and later sold to the estate of Jacob Rutsen Hardenbergh in 1791. Classes were held through the American Revolution in various taverns and boarding houses
column19: and at a building known as College Hall on George Street
column20: until Old Queens was completed and opened in 1811. It remains the oldest building on the Rutgers University campus. The Queen's College Grammar School (now Rutgers Preparatory School) was established also in 1766
column21: and shared facilities with the College until 1830
column22: when it located in a building (now known as Alexander Johnston Hall) across College Avenue from Old Queens. After Rutgers University became the state university of New Jersey in 1945
column23: the Trustees of Rutgers divested itself of Rutgers Preparatory School
column24: which relocated in 1957 to an estate purchased from the Colgate-Palmolive Company in Franklin Township in neighboring Somerset County.The New Brunswick Theological Seminary
column27: sharing its quarters with the fledgling Queen's College. (Queen's closed from 1810 to 1825 due to financial problems
column28: and reopened in 1825 as Rutgers College.) The Seminary
column29: due to overcrowding and differences over the mission of Rutgers College as a secular institution
column30: moved to a tract of land covering 7 acres (2.8 ha) located less than 1⁄2 mile (0.80 km) to the west
column32: although the land is now in the middle of Rutgers University's College Avenue Campus.New Brunswick was formed by royal charter on December 30
column34: within other townships in Middlesex and Somerset counties and was reformed by royal charter with the same boundaries on February 12
column36: at which time it was divided into north and south wards. New Brunswick was incorporated as a city by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on September 1

column1: The existence of an African American community in New Brunswick dates back to the 18th century
column2: when racial slavery was a part of life in the city and the surrounding area. Local slaveholders routinely bought and sold African American children
column4: and men in New Brunswick in the late-eighteenth and early-nineteenth century. In this period
column5: the Market-House was the center of commercial life in the city. It was located at the corner of Hiram Street and Queen Street (now Neilson Street) adjacent to the Raritan Wharf. The site was a place where residents of New Brunswick sold and traded their goods which made it an integral part of the city's economy. The Market-House also served as a site for regular slave auctions and sales.By the late-eighteenth century
column6: New Brunswick became a hub for newspaper production and distribution. The Fredonian
column8: was located less than a block away from the aforementioned Market-House and helped facilitate commercial transactions. A prominent part of the local newspapers were sections dedicated to private owners who would advertise their slaves for sale. The trend of advertising slave sales in newspapers shows that the New Brunswick residents typically preferred selling and buying slaves privately and individually rather than in large groups. The majority of individual advertisements were for female slaves
column9: and their average age at the time of the sale was 20 years old
column10: which was considered the prime age for childbearing. Slave owners would get the most profit from the women who fit into this category because these women had the potential to reproduce another generation of enslaved workers. Additionally
column11: in the urban environment of New Brunswick
column12: there was a high demand for domestic labor
column13: and female workers were preferred for cooking and housework tasks.The New Jersey Legislature passed An Act for the Gradual Abolition of Slavery in 1804. Under the provisions of this law
column14: children born to enslaved women after July 4
column16: would serve their master for a term of 21 years (for girls) or a term of 25 years (for boys)
column18: they would gain their freedom. However
column19: all individuals who were enslaved before July 4
column21: would continue to be slaves for life and would never attain freedom under this law. New Brunswick continued to be home to enslaved African Americans alongside a growing community of free people of color. The 1810 United States Census listed 53 free Blacks and 164 slaves in New Brunswick.

column1: ==== African American spaces and institutions in the early 19th century ====

column2: some free African Americans lived in a section of the city called Halfpenny Town
column3: which was located along the Raritan River by the east side of the city
column4: near Queen (now Neilson) Street. Halfpenny Town was a place populated by free blacks and poorer white people who did not own slaves. This place was known as a social gathering for free blacks that was not completely influenced by white scrutiny and allowed free blacks to socialize among themselves. This does not mean that it was free from white eyes and was still under the negative effects of the slavery era. In the early decades of the nineteenth century
column5: White and either free or enslaved African Americans shared many of the same spaces in New Brunswick
column6: particularly places of worship. The First Presbyterian Church
column8: and First Reformed Church were popular among both Whites and Blacks
column9: and New Brunswick was notable for its lack of spaces where African Americans could congregate exclusively. Most of the time Black congregants of these churches were under the surveillance of Whites. That was the case until the creation of the African Association of New Brunswick in 1817.Both free and enslaved African Americans were active in the establishment of the African Association of New Brunswick
column10: whose meetings were first held in 1817. The African Association of New Brunswick held a meeting every month
column11: mostly in the homes of free blacks. Sometimes these meetings were held at the First Presbyterian Church. Originally intended to provide financial support for the African School of New Brunswick
column12: the African Association grew into a space where blacks could congregate and share ideas on a variety of topics such as religion
column13: abolition and colonization. Slaves were required to obtain a pass from their owner in order to attend these meetings. The African Association worked closely with Whites and was generally favored amongst White residents who believed it would bring more racial peace and harmony to New Brunswick.The African Association of New Brunswick established the African School in 1822. The African School was first hosted in the home of Caesar Rappleyea in 1823. The school was located on the upper end of Church Street in the downtown area of New Brunswick about two blocks away from the jail that held escaped slaves. Both free and enslaved Blacks were welcome to be members of the School. Reverend Huntington (pastor of the First Presbyterian Church) and several other prominent Whites were trustees of the African Association of New Brunswick. These trustees supported the Association which made some slave owners feel safe sending their slaves there by using a permission slip process. The main belief of these White supporters was that Blacks were still unfit for American citizenship and residence
column14: and some trustees were connected with the American Colonization Society that advocated for the migration of free African Americans to Africa. The White trustees only attended some of the meetings of the African Association
column15: and the Association was still unprecedented as a space for both enslaved and free Blacks to get together while under minimal supervision by Whites.The African Association appears to have disbanded after 1824. By 1827
column16: free and enslaved Black people in the city
column18: came together to establish the Mount Zion African Methodist Episcopal Church and purchased a plot of land on Division Street for the purpose of erecting a church building. This was the first African American church in Middlesex County. The church had approximately 30 members in its early years. The church is still in operation and is currently located at 39 Hildebrand Way. The street Hildebrand Way is named after the late Rev. Henry Alphonso Hildebrand
column19: who was pastor of Mount Zion AME for 37 years
column20: which is the longest appointment received by a pastor at Mount Zion AME.Records from the April 1828 census
column21: conducted by the New Brunswick Common Council
column22: state that New Brunswick was populated with 4
column23: 435 white residents and 374 free African Americans. The enslaved population of New Brunswick in 1828 consisted of 57 slaves who must serve for life and 127 slaves eligible for manumission at age 21 or 25 due to the 1804 Act for the Gradual Abolition of Slavery. Free and enslaved African Americans accounted for 11% of New Brunswick's population in 1828
column24: a relatively high percentage for New Jersey. By comparison
column25: as of the 1830 United States Census
column26: African Americans made up approximately 6.4% of the total population of New Jersey.

column1: ==== Jail and curfew in the 19th century ====

column2: the New Brunswick Common Council adopted a curfew for free people of color. Free African Americans were not allowed to be out after 10 PM on Saturday night. The Common Council also appointed a committee of white residents who were charged with rounding up and detaining free African Americans who appeared to be out of place according to white authorities.New Brunswick became a notorious city for slave hunters
column3: who sought to enforce the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850. Strategically located on the Raritan River
column4: the city was also a vital hub for New Jersey's Underground Railroad. For runaway slaves in New Jersey
column5: it served as a favorable route for those heading to New York and Canada. When African Americans tried to escape either to or from New Brunswick
column6: they had a high likelihood of getting discovered and captured and sent to New Brunswick's jail
column7: which was located on Prince Street
column8: which by now is renamed Bayard Street.

column1: New Brunswick has been described as the nation's "most Hungarian city"
column2: with Hungarian immigrants arriving in the city as early as 1888 and accounting for almost 20% of the city's population in 1915. Hungarians were primarily attracted to the city by employment at Johnson & Johnson factories located in the city. Hungarians settled mainly in what today is the Fifth Ward and businesses were established to serve the needs of the Hungarian community that weren't being met by mainstream businesses. The immigrant population grew until the end of the immigration boom in the early 20th century.
the community was revitalized by the decision to process the tens of thousands refugees who came to the United States from the failed 1956 Hungarian Revolution at Camp Kilmer
column3: in nearby Edison. Even though the Hungarian population has been largely supplanted by newer immigrants
column4: there continues to be a Hungarian Festival in the city held on Somerset Street on the first Saturday of June each year; the 44th annual event was held in 2019. Many Hungarian institutions set up by the community remain and are active in the neighborhood
column5: including: Magyar Reformed Church
column8: St. Joseph Byzantine Catholic Church
column16: Bolyai Lecture Series on Arts and Sciences
column20: Committee of Hungarian Churches and Organizations of New Brunswick

column1: Several landmarks in the city also testify to its Hungarian heritage. There is a street and a park named after Lajos Kossuth
column2: one of the leaders of the Hungarian Revolution of 1848. The corner of Somerset Street and Plum Street is named Mindszenty Square where the first ever statue of Cardinal József Mindszenty was erected. A stone memorial to the victims of the 1956 Hungarian Revolution stands nearby.
about 50% of New Brunswick's population is self-identified as Hispanic
column3: the 14th highest percentage among municipalities in New Jersey. Since the 1960s
column4: many of the new residents of New Brunswick have come from Latin America. Many citizens moved from Puerto Rico in the 1970s. In the 1980s
column5: many immigrated from the Dominican Republic
column8: Ecuador and Mexico.

column2: revitalization and redevelopment ===

column1: New Brunswick is one of nine cities in New Jersey designated as eligible for Urban Transit Hub Tax Credits by the state's Economic Development Authority. Developers who invest a minimum of $50 million within a half-mile of a train station are eligible for pro-rated tax credit.New Brunswick contains a number of examples of urban renewal in the United States. In the 1960s-1970s
column2: the downtown area became blighted as middle class residents moved to newer suburbs surrounding the city
column3: an example of the phenomenon known as "white flight." Beginning in 1975

column6: with the goal of revitalizing the city center and redeveloping neighborhoods considered to be blighted and dangerous (via demolition of existing buildings and construction of new ones). Johnson & Johnson announced in 1978 that they would remain in New Brunswick and invest $50 million to build a new world headquarters building in the area between Albany Street

column2: along with several medical teaching and research institutions including Saint Peter's University Hospital

column1: Portions of the city are part of an Urban Enterprise Zone (UEZ)
column2: one of 32 zones covering 37 municipalities statewide. New Brunswick was selected in 2004 as one of two zones added to participate in the program. In addition to other benefits to encourage employment and investment within the Zone
column3: shoppers can take advantage of a reduced 3.3125% sales tax rate (half of the ​6 5⁄8% rate charged statewide) at eligible merchants. Established in December 2004
column4: the city's Urban Enterprise Zone status expires in December 2024.

column2: Crossroads Theatre designed by Parsons+Fernandez-Casteleiro Architects from New York. In 1999
column3: the Crossroads Theatre won the prestigious Tony Award for Outstanding Regional Theatre. Crossroads is the first African American theater to receive this honor in the 33-year history of this special award category. George Street Playhouse (founded in 1974) and the State Theatre (constructed in 1921 for vaudeville and silent films) also form the heart of the local theatre scene. Crossroad Theatre houses American Repertory Ballet and the Princeton Ballet School. Rutgers University has student-run companies such as Cabaret Theatre
column4: The Livingston Theatre Company
column5: and College Avenue Players which perform everything from musicals to dramatic plays to sketch comedy.

column1: Owing in part to its abundance of Rutgers University graduates
column2: New Brunswick has developed a rich history in homegrown journalism over the years. One current news outlet is New Brunswick Today a print and digital publication launched in 2011 by Rutgers journalism alumnus Charlie Kratovil which uses the tagline "Independent news for the greater New Brunswick community". The publication has covered issues with the city's water utility among others and was featured on Full Frontal with Samantha Bee.

column1: The "Grease trucks" were a group of truck-based food vendors located on the College Avenue campus of Rutgers University. They were known for serving "Fat Sandwiches
column2:
sub rolls containing several ingredients such as steak, chicken fingers, French fries, falafel, cheeseburgers, mozzarella sticks, gyro meat, bacon, eggs and marinara sauce. In 2013 the grease trucks were removed for the construction of a new Rutgers building and were forced to move into various other areas of the Rutgers-New Brunswick Campus.


=== Music ===
New Brunswick's bar scene has been the home to many original rock bands, including some which went on to national prominence such as The Smithereens and Bon Jovi, as well as a center for local punk rock and underground music. Many alternative rock bands got radio airplay thanks to Matt Pinfield who was part of the New Brunswick music scene for over 20 years at Rutgers University radio station WRSU. Local pubs and clubs hosted many local bands, including the Court Tavern until 2012 (since reopened), and the Melody Bar during the 1980s and 1990s. As the New Brunswick basement scene grows in popularity, it was ranked the number 4 spot to see Indie bands in New Jersey.  In March 2017, NJ.com wrote that even if Asbury Park has recently returned as our state's musical nerve center
column3: with the brick-and-mortar venues and infrastructure to prove it
column4: New Brunswick remains as the New Jersey scene's unadulterated
column5: pounding heart."

column1: The City of New Brunswick is governed within the Faulkner Act
column2: formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law
column3: under the Mayor-Council system of municipal government. The city is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide governed under this form. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the five-member City Council
column4: all of whom are elected at-large on a partisan basis to four-year terms of office in even-numbered years as part of the November general election. The City Council's five members are elected on a staggered basis
column5: with either two or three seats coming up for election every other year and the mayor up for election at the same time that two council seats are up for vote. As the legislative body of New Brunswick's municipal government
column6: the City Council is responsible for approving the annual budget
column8: contracts
column9: and appointments to boards and commissions. The Council President is elected to a two-year term by the members of the Council at a reorganization meeting held after election and presides over all meetings.As of 2020
column10: Democrat James Cahill is the 62nd Mayor of New Brunswick; he was sworn in as Mayor on January 1
column11: 1991 and is serving a term that expires on December 31
column12: 2022. Members of the City Council are Council President John A. Andersen (D
column14: Council Vice President Suzanne M. Sicora Ludwig (D

column1: The New Brunswick Police Department has received attention for various incidents over the years. In 1991
column2: the fatal shooting of Shaun Potts
column4: by Sergeant Zane Grey led to multiple local protests.  In 1996
column5: Officer James Consalvo fatally shot Carolyn "Sissy" Adams
column6: an unarmed prostitute who had bit him. The Adams case sparked calls for reform in the New Brunswick Police Department
column7: and ultimately was settled with the family. Two officers
column8: Sgt. Marco Chinchilla and Det. James Marshall
column9: were convicted of running a bordello in 2001. Chinchilla was sentenced to three years and Marshall was sentenced to four. In 2011
column10: Officer Brad Berdel fatally shot Barry Deloatch
column11: a black man who had run from police (although police claim he struck officers with a stick); this sparked daily protests from residents.Following the Deloatch shooting
column12: sergeant Richard Rowe was formally charged with mishandling 81 Internal Affairs investigations; Mayor Cahill explained that this would help "rebuild the public's trust and confidence in local law enforcement."

column1: The current professional city fire department was established in 1914
column2: but the earliest volunteer fire company in the city dates back to 1764. The department operates out of three stations
column3: with a total of approximately 80 officers and firefighters.

column1: The New Brunswick Parking Authority manages 14 ground-level and multi-story parking facilities across the city. CitiPark manages a downtown parking facility at 2 Albany Street.
New Brunswick is served by NJ Transit and Amtrak trains on the Northeast Corridor Line. NJ Transit provides frequent service north to Pennsylvania Station
column2: in Midtown Manhattan
column4: while Amtrak's Keystone Service and Northeast Regional trains service the New Brunswick station. The Jersey Avenue station is also served by Northeast Corridor trains. For other Amtrak connections
column5: riders can take NJ Transit to Penn Station (New York or Newark)

column1: Local bus service is provided by NJ Transit's 810
column5: 818 routes and 980 route.Also available is the extensive Rutgers Campus bus network. Middlesex County Area Transit (MCAT) shuttles provide service on routes operating across the county
column7: which operates between Jamesburg and the New Brunswick train station. DASH/CAT buses
column8: operated by Somerset County on the 851 and 852 routes connect New Brunswick and Bound Brook.Suburban Trails offers service to and from New York City on Route 100 between Princeton and the Port Authority Bus Terminal; on Route 500 between New Brunswick and along 42nd Street to the United Nations; and Route 600 between East Windsor and Wall Street in Downtown Manhattan. Studies are being conducted to create the New Brunswick Bus Rapid Transit system.
